awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Aerodynamic-aeroacoustic performance of poroelastic wings inspired by the silent plumage of owls
awd_abstract_narration:
Owls are extraordinary predators that are able to suppress their noise and achieve silent flight while attacking prey/food. The wing fringe pattern of owls is believed to contribute to their quiet flight. An understanding of the physics of the flow over owl wings may lead to noise reductions for many engineering designs, such as computer fans, propulsors, commercial airframes, and wind turbines. The principal aim of this project is to analyze a series of analytical and numerical model problems coordinated with experimental measurement to elucidate the unsteady loading and noise generation of thin fluid-loaded structures with graded poroelastic properties comparable to owl wings. 

This project addresses the above technical shortcomings through an interactive theoretical-experimental program that distinguishes itself in no fewer than three ways: (i) construction of analytical and numerical frameworks to predict turbulence noise generation by graded poroelastic structures, from first principles; (ii) experimental validation of acoustic scaling laws for poroelastic edges, without background flow noise; and (iii) development of a glider to measure wing noise on the fly in a manner consistent with how owls hear their self-noise. The modeling and validation efforts aim to transform a biologically-inspired noise solution into a rational paradigm for passive aerodynamic noise control in low-speed flows and to create an experimental platform for future bionic owl noise-reduction studies. This project will also include K-12 educational outreach with the DaVinci Science Center (Allentown, PA), as well as integrate undergraduate research involvement through the Lehigh Biosystems Dynamics Summer Institute (in partnership with Northampton Community College) and through a design-build-fly competition between Lehigh and Penn State.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This project is motivated by the capacity of owl wings to reduce aerodynamic noise, which is a byproduct of flight through the air that is continuously produced at the wing trailing edge. Specifically, this research program is driven by the need to identify how the effects of porous or elastic wing features on flight noise can be predicted by theoretical models and organized in a way to permit direct experimental validation. Both aeroacoustic and aerodynamic effects are considered, with the view to inform a potential performance trade-off between noise reduction and the loss of lift or flight stability when considering porous or elastic wing designs.

The intellectual merit of this program is reflected in several novel contributions to the theoretical modeling of the aerodynamic forces and the aerodynamic noise production of porous or elastic wings, which are of direct interest to the fluid mechanics, aerospace, and energy communities, among others. These contributions include: an explicit solution to the aerodynamics of wings in steady flight with an arbitrary distribution of porosity; the first formulation and solution of generalized porous wings in unsteady aerodynamic environments, such as wing flapping or gust encounters; a predictive framework for the coupled movements of aerodynamics gusts and a flapping or flexible wing, as well as the resulting noise production; and the theoretical confirmation that porosity does not change the manner in which flexible panels become unstable at high speeds. 

Earlier theoretical work suggested that porous edges in fluid flows may produce noise with a different sound field shape and noise level dependence on the flow speed. In an effort to circumvent the background noise of traditional wind tunnels that would corrupt this sensitive measurement for porous edges, a theoretical model based on vortex rings shot past a porous edge in still air is constructed. This model confirms the results of prior work and identifies additional metrics for experimental validation, which is carried out in collaboration with Applied Research Laboratory at Pennsylvania State University.

The broader impact of this research program stems chiefly from the interdisciplinary reach of its scientific outcomes and from the research development of undergraduate and graduate students. This research program produced an invited review on the aeroacoustic modeling and available measurements of owl wings, which identifies several ways forward for how the engineering  and biology communities can address the challenge of silent owl flight and translate this knowledge to quieter wing and blade designs operating a low speeds, such as on wind turbines. In addition, this program enabled the support of several undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in engineering in partnership with Lehigh University?s STEM-SI program. Mentored by the graduate students on the project, these undergraduates constructed a radio-controlled air vehicle at owl scale to measure the noise from porous wing designs on the wing and on the fuselage where the owl would hear its own noise. Unique graduate student opportunities were also provided through an extended residence at Applied Research Laboratory at Pennsylvania State University to learn acoustical processing techniques and take part in new collaborative research projects specific to a national laboratory.


Last Modified: 09/27/2022
Modified by: Justin W Jaworski

Images (1 of )
  • The sound production mechanism of turbulent flows near an edge can be neatly replicated with a vortex ring. The sound field shape becomes dipolar with increasing effective porosity (left), which is accompanied by a change in the acoustic time signal (right) that can be compared with experiments.
    Huansheng Chen, Justin Jaworski
    Copyrighted
    Justin W Jaworski
    Sound from vortex rings near porous edges
  • Owl-sized glider developed by a graduate student and several Lehigh undergraduates through the STEM-SI summer research program. The experimental aircraft enables the testing of various porous edge designs for noise reduction on a flying vehicle.
    Christa Neu, Justin Jaworski
    Copyrighted
    Justin W Jaworski
    Lehigh STEM-SI vertically-integrated research
